Source: A Cloud Guru. [Original PDF at this URL](https://acloudguru-content-attachment-production.s3-accelerate.amazonaws.com/1626978078175-DP-900_StudyGuide.pdf). Accessed [[April 20th, 2022]]. > A data structure that copies and re-orders data or contains pointers to data to improve the speed of data retrieval operations, often at the cost of speed for write operations. #QuizQuestion #DP900 #Definition

Most [[Relational]] database management systems (RDMSs) support clustered and nonclustered indexes. The difference is that a table is physically sorted in clustered index order when it is used and a nonclustered index does not change the table order, but it contains pointers to the appropriate table rows." #Fact
> "An index is the structure used to sort value to help optimize query performance." #QuizQuestion #DP900
Source: [Views - Azure Data Explorer | Microsoft Docs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/data-explorer/kusto/query/schema-entities/views)
Accessed: [[April 19th, 2022]]
> "A view is a virtual table whose contents is defined through a query." #Definition
A simple view might look like the following:

```[[SQL]]
CREATE VIEW CustLabels
AS
SELECT c.CustomerNumber, c.CustomerName
FROM Customer c```
This would create a view that includes CustomerNumber and CustomerNamecolumn values. Once created, a view can be used as a data source on other queries.
>  "BLANK is a virtual table whose contents is defined through a query." #QuizQuestion #DP900

title: describe and compare PaaS, IaaS, and SaaS solutions

children.string: Source: [Azure [[SQL]] Database  Managed Cloud Database Service | Microsoft Azure](https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/products/azure-[[SQL]]/database/#features)
Accessed: [[April 19th, 2022]]

> "Azure [[SQL]] Database is a fully managed [[Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS)]] database engine in the cloud that handles most of the database management functions such as upgrading, patching, backups, and monitoring without user involvement." #Definition
You should use Azure [[SQL]] Database for inventory management and finance and accounting system workloads, because Azure [[SQL]] Database provides high data integrity and normalized schema. #UseCase

To connect to a [[Relational]] data service from corporate network, the following port should be open for outbound traffic: 1433.Your network firewall should allow communication over these ports to be able to connect to these [[Relational]] data services. #Fact

Source: [What is Azure Database for Postgre[[SQL]] | Microsoft Docs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/postgre[[SQL]]/overview)
Accessed: [[April 19th, 2022]]
> "Azure Database for Postgre[[SQL]] is a [[Relational]] database service in the Microsoft cloud based on thePostgre[[SQL]] open source [[Relational]] database." #Definition
Azure Database for Postgre[[SQL]] can be deployed as a single server or as a cluster. #Fact

Azure Database for Postgre[[SQL]] enforces Transport Layer Security ([[TLS]]) connections by default. Enforcing [[TLS]] connections improves security by encrypting the connection between the client and the database server. #Fact
Azure Database for Postgre[[SQL]] supports AD authentication. #Fact

"An indirect relationship between data elements in a database. The rule is essentially that A is a [[Transitive Dependency]] of C (A->C) if A is functionally dependent on B (A->B), and B is functionally dependent on C (B->C) but not on A (B not->A)." #Definition

"Social security number is a transitive dependency of date-of-birth (SSN->DOB), because social security number is dependent on employee name (SSN->EMP), and employee name is dependent on date-of-birth (EMP->DOB) but not on social security number (there may be more than one John Smith or Maria Gomez)." #UseCase

"A [[[[Relational]] Database]] is a type of database that stores and provides access to data points that are related to one another. [[Relational]][databases]are based on the [[Relational]] model, an intuitive, straightforward way of representing data in [[Tables]]. In a [[[[Relational]] Database]], each row in the table is a record with a unique ID called the [[Primary Key]]. The columns of the table hold attributes of the data, and each record usually has a value for each attribute, making it easy to establish the relationships among data points." #Definition

> "Data for batch processing is collected over time, often from different data sources, and it is processed as a dataset that includes a range of rows or all rows in the dataset. Batch processing is designed to handle processing of large dataset. There is typically a long latency between data collection and data processing." #Definition
The following application are best suited to batch processing:
Employee payroll processing and generating payroll checks
Setting inventory stocking levels based on seasonal sales volume

>  "Data for BLANK is collected over time, often from different data sources, and it is processed as a dataset that includes a range of rows or all rows in the dataset. It is designed to handle processing of large dataset. There is typically a long latency between data collection and data processing." #QuizQuestion #DP900

> "Stream Processing is designed for real-time or near real-time processing often as a data load process with minimal processing. Data must be able to stream out as quickly as it streams in for processing. Data is either processed as it is generated or in micro-batches of a very few rows with latency of no more than a few milliseconds (very short latency)." #Definition
Reporting the number of users and bandwidth user for an online game.
Identifying detected manufacturing errors to automatically reject failing parts.
Data from from sensors and IoT devices.
Real-time data from users navigating in a website

Source: [Clustered and nonclustered indexes described - [[SQL]] Server | Microsoft Docs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/[[SQL]]/[[Relational]]-databases/indexes/clustered-and-nonclustered-indexes-described?view=[[SQL]]-server-ver15)
Accessed: [[April 19th, 2022]]
> " A clustered index is a data structure associated with a table that defines the order in which rows are stored on a disk." #Definition
Only one clustered index per table can be defined, because the clustered index defines how data rows are sorted and stored. #Fact
A table with an implemented clustered index is called a **clustered table**.
> " BLANK is a data structure associated with a table that defines the order in which rows are stored on a disk." #QuizQuestion #DP900
> "Partitioning is a mechanism for grouping related rows, based on a common property or [[Partition Key]]. Rows that share the same [[Partition Key]] will be stored together." #Definition
Partitions are independent from each other, and can grow or shrink as rows are added to, or removed from, a partition. A table can contain any number of partitions.

When you search for data, you can include the [[Partition Key]] in the search criteria. This helps to narrow down the volume of data to be examined, and improves performance by reducing the amount of I/O (input and output operations, or__reads__and__writes__) needed to locate the data.
Partitioning not only helps to organize data, it can also improve scalability and performance in the following ways: #Fact

Distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks are some of the largest availability and security concerns facing customers that are moving their applications to the cloud. A DDoS attack attempts to exhaust an application's resources, making the application unavailable to legitimate users. DDoS attacks can be targeted at any endpoint that is publicly reachable through the internet.

Example use cases: #UseCase

The verify operation takes face and determines if it belongs to the same person as another face. You need to detect face(s) in an image using the Detect API. The Verify operation can then compare two faces.
The Find Similar operation takes a face you have detected and extracts faces that look alike from a list of faces that you provide. Find Similar returns a subset of the faces in the list.

The Group operation creates several smaller groups from a list of faces based on the similarities of the faces. The Group operation needs between two and 1000 faces. You should not use the Group operation to evaluate two faces. You should use Verify to evaluate two faces.

The Identify operation takes one or more face(s) and matches them to people. The Identify operation returns a list of possible matches with a confidence score between 0 and 1, with 1 being the most confident. You should not use the Identify operation to evaluate whether two faces belong to the same person.

Data shaping involves cleaning, shaping, and re-organising data in(to) tabular format. #DP900 #PL300 #Definition
A first step is often to identify headers and column names and [[Promote headers]].
You can [[Rename columns]] and [[Rename rows]] either by right-clicking the column header for a contextual menu, or double clicking the header.
You can [[Remove columns]] and [[remove rows]] to reduce the size of your imported data tables and achieve [[Normalization]].
[[Pivot]] turns distinct row values into columns - or a vertical format into horizontal.
[[Unpivot]] turns column into distinct rows.
[[Transpose]] performs a similar role to [[Pivot]] and [[Unpivot]], but does not recognise repeated values and collapse them into a single/row or column, rather preserving duplicates.
Data profiling allows you to assess the content and quality of your data, including null values, data errors, and statistics on the distribution of values within the data. #PL300 #DP900
The [[View Menu]] in [[Power Query]] contains tools for data profiling.
[[Column Quality]] shows percentages within a column across categories 'valid', 'error', 'empty'.
[[Column Distribution]] provides a sample distribution of the data contained within a column, e.g. distinct vs unique values in a column.
[[Column Profile]] provides a holistic view of the data, including column statistics such as count, errors, distinct and unique values, and minimum and maximum values.

Enhancing data structures in PowerBI includes making column and query names human-readable and consistent, assigning appropriate datatypes to columns, and changing the structure of tables by [[Merging Queries]] or [[Appending Queries]] #PL300 #DP900 #Definition
Merging Queries joins two queries (tables) together based on a common field (column). #DP900 #PL300 #Definition
BLANK joins two queries (tables) together based on a common field (column). #DP900 #PL300 #QuizQuestion
[[Left outer join]] - all from first, only matching from second.
[[Right outer join]] - all from second, only matching from first.
[[Full outer join]] - all rows from both.
[[Inner join]] - only matching rows.
[[Left Anti-join]] - rows only in the first (eliminates matching rows with the second table).
[[Right Anti-join]] - rows only in the second (eliminates matching rows with the first).
All columns from the first table, plus only matching columns from the second.
All rows from both tables.
All columns from the second table, only matching columns from the first.
Produces a table with only matching rows between the two tables.
Produces rows only in the first table, eliminating matching rows with the second table.
Produces rows only in the second table, eliminating matching rows with the first table.
